Description: Jar. Fritware (stonepaste). The cylindrical jar with fluted (lobed?) body, straight neck and a bead rim sits on a thick, wide foot ring. The inside is covered with a pale blue glaze and painted with a (pseudo?) inscription in lustre on the neck. On the exterior, the rim is painted in lustre. The neck shows a row of large-scale kneeling figures alternating with the sides divided into rectangular compartments, and arabesques reserved in white on a lustre ground. Rayy type. Fritware (stonepaste); painted in lustre over an opaque white glaze.
Curator's comments: In the 1170s, a group of Iranian potters at Kashan adopted the complex glazing technique that produces the glazed surface known today as lustre. This had previously only been used in Egypt, Syria and Iraq. The shining metallic surface of these wares is the product of decorating glazed objects with oxides of copper and silver and submitting them to a second firing at low temperatures in a so-called reducing kiln (Blurton 1997). This jar is representative of the earliest group of Kashan lustrewares, decorated in the 'monumental' style as termed by Oliver Watson. The round-cheeked, narrow-eyed faces reflect a vogue for Chinese-style figures made familiar in Iran, perhaps inspired by portable Buddhist sculpture or painting in the eastern Iranian world. Seated figures such as the eight on this jar have no specific meaning but were intended to suggest enjoyment and good living. The object was formerly thought to have been made in Rayy.
